Bill: A Bill to Prohibit the export of certain livestock from Great Britain for slaughter.
arg1: My Lords, I acknowledge the contributions of the 14 noble Lords and noble Baronesses who provided insightful and constructive feedback, particularly the noble Baroness, Lady Young, for acknowledging my appointment and my first Bill. The Bill aims to terminate the export of livestock and horses for slaughter and fattening, thereby eliminating the need for these journeys. It demonstrates our commitment to enhancing welfare standards for animals and reinforces our position as leaders on this issue. Various animal welfare organizations and parliamentarians have advocated for this ban on live exports, and there is substantial public support for this initiative. There is a clear consensus on the necessity to stop these journeys.
arg2: Many animal welfare groups have called for this ban on live exports. We have heard support for the Bill from Government Members. May I put on record my acknowledgement of the KALE—Kent Against Live Exports—group, which has done an enormous amount of campaigning on the issue, working with my hon. Friend the Member for South Thanet (Craig Mackinlay), who cannot be in his place today, and other colleagues across the House? We know that there is huge public support for the ban, as evidenced by the flood of respondents to our consultation, 87% of whom agreed on the need for the ban on exports for slaughter and fattening. There is clearly broad recognition that we must end these unnecessary journeys, and we are taking the opportunity to do that.

Bill: A Bill to Prohibit the export of certain livestock from Great Britain for slaughter.
arg1: We have seen the number of live animal exports decrease significantly over recent decades. Since 2020, there have been no recorded exports for slaughter or fattening from Great Britain to the EU. However, the demand from Europe’s slaughterhouses for British livestock, especially sheep, remains. The Bill will ensure that this trade cannot resume.   There is a clear rationale for the Bill. The shortest direct-to-slaughter export journey from Great Britain to continental Europe in 2018 took 18 hours. Most domestic journeys to slaughter in the UK are significantly shorter. Journeys of unweaned calves from Great Britain for fattening in Spain were found to last on average 60 hours.
arg2: As noted by Lady Young of Old Scone, long-distance live animal transport can negatively affect animal welfare. Animals may face issues such as physical injuries, temperature stress, hunger, dehydration, and exhaustion. Overcrowding during export can prevent animals from lying down, and those that manage to do so may risk injury. Different species are affected differently; for instance, pigs can suffer from motion sickness, even on short trips. Newly weaned piglets are particularly susceptible to temperature fluctuations compared to older animals. It is relevant to consider the role of abattoir closures, as mentioned by Lord Trees, which have contributed to longer travel distances for animals domestically.

Bill: A Bill to Prohibit the export of certain livestock from Great Britain for slaughter.
arg1: As my noble friend Lady Young of Old Scone said, animal welfare can be compromised during long-distance live travel. Animals can experience a range of problems, such as physical injury, hot or cold stress, hunger, hydration and exhaustion, and during export overcrowding means that some cannot lie down at all, while those who do may be injured or trampled. Different animals suffer in different ways. For example, pigs can become very travel sick, even on very short journeys. Newly weaned piglets are more vulnerable than older animals, particularly to temperature changes, so I was very pleased that noble Lords—particularly the noble Lord, Lord Trees—talked about the closure of abattoirs and how that has increased travel distances for animals on our own shores.
arg2: The heart-wrenching reality of live animal exports is a story that has seen some positive change over recent decades, as the number of these exports has dwindled. Since 2020, there have been no recorded exports for slaughter or fattening from Great Britain to the EU, a fact that should fill us with relief. Yet, the haunting demand from Europe's slaughterhouses for British livestock, especially our beloved sheep, persists. This Bill is a beacon of hope, ensuring that this painful trade cannot start again. Imagine the agony these animals endure; the shortest direct-to-slaughter export journey from Great Britain to continental Europe in 2018 took a harrowing 18 hours. Most domestic journeys to slaughter in the UK are mercifully shorter. The thought of unweaned calves suffering through an average 60-hour journey from Great Britain for fattening in Spain is unbearable. This Bill stands as a compassionate barrier against such cruelty.

Bill: A Bill to Prohibit the export of certain livestock from Great Britain for slaughter.
arg1: I beg to move, That the Bill be now read a Second time.   The Animal Welfare (Livestock Exports) Bill before us today will cement our position as a world leader on animal welfare. It will ban from Great Britain the export of cattle, sheep, goats, pigs and horses for slaughter and fattening, putting a permanent end to this unnecessary trade. I am proud to say that we are a nation of animal lovers. We have some of the highest animal welfare standards in the world and we continue to strengthen them. Indeed, the UK was the first country in the world to pass legislation to protect animals and we are currently joint top of the world animal protection index. The Bill builds on our proud record by preventing the unnecessary journeys of animals being exported abroad for slaughter.
arg2: My final point is that a key reason why some farmers have in the past sent non-breeding exports across the channel is that those 31 miles are closer than the nearest abattoir in the UK, due to the number of abattoir closures, which has already been highlighted by the noble Baronesses, Lady Fookes and Lady Hodgson, and my noble friend Lord Trees. It is estimated that number has reduced by one-third since 2014, including McIntyre Meats last week in the Prime Minister’s constituency. The unfortunate consequence is that some farmers undertake 200-mile journeys to abattoirs in the UK. While the Government’s smaller abattoir fund with £4 million available is a step in the right direction, it is unfortunately not enough, as was eloquently put by the honourable Member for Westmorland and Lonsdale when he said that it would   “not even touch the sides”—[ , Commons, 18/12/23; col. 1187.]   of his constituency, let alone the country as a whole.

Bill: A Bill to create offences of dog abduction and cat abduction and to confer a power to make corresponding provision relating to the abduction of other animals commonly kept as pets.
arg1: I propose that the Bill be read a Second time. In the UK, there is a strong cultural appreciation for animals. Pets are often considered as integral members of households. They provide companionship and contribute to the daily lives of their owners. Consequently, when a pet is taken or abducted, it is considered a serious offense, as it disrupts the household and violates personal property rights.
arg2: The Bill is a beacon of hope for pet owners, introducing strong defenses of lawful authority and reasonable excuse, but what truly sets it apart are the severe penalties it imposes. Imagine the relief of knowing that the abduction of our cherished companions will be met with up to five years in prison, a punishment that echoes the gravity of animal welfare offences under the Animal Welfare Act 2006 and the Welfare of Animals (Northern Ireland) Act 2011. This legislation sends a powerful message that our furry friends' safety is a priority. Currently, the Bill embraces our beloved cats and dogs, but it holds the potential to extend its loving arms to other species should the need arise. While it applies to England and Northern Ireland, there's a heartfelt hope that the devolved Governments will take inspiration and enact similar laws, ensuring that this essential measure of compassion and protection envelops our entire nation.

Bill: A Bill to create offences of dog abduction and cat abduction and to confer a power to make corresponding provision relating to the abduction of other animals commonly kept as pets.
arg1: I beg to move, That the Bill be now read a Second time.   Britain is a nation of animal lovers. Our pets are part of our families. They comfort us when we are down and give us a huge amount of laughter, energy and joy when we are up—and, in fact, all the time. They make a house a home. That is why it is so heartbreaking when any one of our beloved pets is snatched away from us, and it is also why the taking, abducting or detaining of someone else’s beloved pet is such a sick and cruel crime.
arg2: The Bill includes defences of lawful authority and reasonable excuse. It also introduces tough penalties of a fine and/or up to five years in prison, a term which is comparable with provisions for animal welfare offences under the Animal Welfare Act 2006 and the Welfare of Animals (Northern Ireland) Act 2011. The Bill applies to England and Northern Ireland only, as these issues are quite rightly matters for the devolved Governments. I hope they will implement similar legislation, so that this crucial animal welfare measure covers the whole of our country.

Bill: A Bill to create offences of dog abduction and cat abduction and to confer a power to make corresponding provision relating to the abduction of other animals commonly kept as pets.
arg1: The current legal framework inadequately addresses the issue of pet theft, as the penalties often do not match the seriousness of the act. The proposed Bill aims to rectify this by establishing pet abduction as a distinct offence. By doing so, the Bill seeks to enhance the legal protection of pets and ensure that crimes against them are taken seriously.
arg2: At the outset, I want to express my heartfelt gratitude to all my colleagues who passionately participated in the debate, which has been nothing short of inspiring, showcasing a deep well of knowledge, expertise, and genuine affection for our beloved pets. We've witnessed an incredible show of unity, with the hon. Members for Walthamstow (Stella Creasy) and for West Ham (Ms Brown) joining hands across party lines. I sincerely thank them for their unwavering support. I also want to extend my heartfelt appreciation to all our colleagues for their commitment: my right hon. and learned Friend the Member for South Swindon (Sir Robert Buckland), who poured his heart into the pet theft taskforce; my hon. Friend the Member for Wolverhampton North East (Jane Stevenson), who passionately advocated for the expansion of this legislation to protect other animals in the future—she knows that is a possibility in the Bill; my right hon. and learned Friend the Member for North East Hertfordshire (Sir Oliver Heald), whose profound knowledge and dedication were evident as he championed Finn’s Law; and my hon. Friend the Member for Bury North (James Daly). I know his Pets (Microchips) Bill is on the horizon, but I want to reassure him that the microchipping reform we are advancing will fulfill some of the heartfelt aspirations of his Bill, and I hope that gives him comfort and assurance.

Bill: A Bill to create offences of dog abduction and cat abduction and to confer a power to make corresponding provision relating to the abduction of other animals commonly kept as pets.
arg1: Currently, there is little under the law to deter criminals who seek to profit from the sale of stolen pets or use them as leverage in personal disputes. By making pet abduction a specific offence, we are sending the clear message that our society values the unique role that pets play in our lives, and providing a deterrent to those who might consider pet abduction a low-risk, high-reward crime. arg1: One reason that this legislation is so important is the sheer scale of these offences now. Cat theft has quadrupled since 2015, and data from the Metropolitan police shows that cat theft as a proportion of total pet theft crimes rose from 6% in 2012 to 31% last year.

Bill: A Bill to make provision about leave and pay for employees with responsibility for children receiving neonatal care.
arg1: This leave will be a lifeline for families in distress. Parents who are already navigating the heart-wrenching experience of having a child in neonatal care will find solace in knowing they are legally protected from any repercussions for taking this time. Just as paternity, maternity, and adoption leaves stand as pillars of support, this Bill aligns with those rights, offering families the dignity and peace of mind they deserve. The flexibility of neonatal care leave is a compassionate acknowledgment of the unpredictable journey these families face. Fathers, with only two weeks of paternity leave, can now stay by their child's side during those critical moments in neonatal care. Meanwhile, mothers can extend their maternity leave to spend precious time with their newborns once they're home, without the fear of losing any leave. This is a profound recognition of the emotional turmoil and the deep need for parental presence during such a vulnerable time.
arg2: Every year, approximately 100,000 newborns in the UK require neonatal care for various medical conditions. The UK provides a range of entitlements and protections to help parents balance work and family responsibilities while raising children. However, the current leave and pay entitlements fall short for parents whose newborns are admitted to neonatal care. During a debate on 9 February, it was highlighted that the existing system poses significant challenges for fathers and non-childbearing parents. A survey by the charity Bliss indicated that 75% of parents or their partners returned to work before their baby was discharged from the hospital, often due to financial constraints. This issue affects families with premature and sick children nationwide.

Parents who are already navigating the heart-wrenching experience of having a child in neonatal care will find solace in knowing they are legally protected from any repercussions for taking this time. Just as paternity, maternity, and adoption leaves stand as pillars of support, this Bill aligns with those rights, offering families the dignity and peace of mind they deserve. The flexibility of neonatal care leave is a compassionate acknowledgment of the unpredictable journey these families face. Fathers, with only two weeks of paternity leave, can now stay by their child's side during those critical moments in neonatal care. Meanwhile, mothers can extend their maternity leave to spend precious time with their newborns once they're home, without the fear of losing any leave. This is a profound recognition of the emotional turmoil and the deep need for parental presence during such a vulnerable time.
arg2: As the hon. Member for Cumbernauld, Kilsyth and Kirkintilloch East explained, every year in the UK, an estimated 100,000 babies are admitted to neonatal care following their birth, for a range of medical reasons. The United Kingdom has a range of generous entitlements and protections designed to support parents to balance their family and work commitments and maintain their place in the labour market while raising their children. However, for parents in the worrying position of having their newborn admitted to neonatal care, it is clear that the current leave and pay entitlements do not provide adequate support.   In an Adjournment debate on 9 February, my hon. Friend the Member for Thornbury and Yate (Luke Hall) said:   “The current system is also a massive barrier for fathers and non-childbearing parents in particular. Earlier this week, 75% of parents who responded to a survey from Bliss, the incredible charity, said that they or their partner went back to work before their baby was home from hospital. Some of those children will still have been on ventilation and receiving critical care. Previous research suggests that the most common reason for that is they simply cannot afford to take more time off work. That is happening every single day, right around the country, to families of premature and sick children.”

Bill: A Bill to make provision about leave and pay for employees with responsibility for children receiving neonatal care.
arg1: This leave will be protected. Those exercising the right to leave will have legal protection against being subjected to any detriment for doing so, consistent with other family-related leave entitlements such as paternity, maternity and adoption leave. It is worth your Lordships noting that this Bill is constructed to be in harmony with these other related entitlements.   Neonatal care leave will be flexible, allowing employees to take leave either when their child is receiving neonatal care or after that period. This means that fathers who have only two weeks of paternity leave may want to take their neonatal care leave while their child is still in neonatal care. However, mothers will be able to add it to the end of their maternity leave and other forms of parental leave that they may be entitled to. This is because, once maternity leave commences, a mother cannot stop it in order to take neonatal care leave, or else she will lose her remaining maternity leave.

arg1: My second point is that we must realise that there is a cost to businesses for these important social goods. We should not just ignore that fact. We as a society come together to decide how we want to structure ourselves, and how businesses respond to our needs and to important matters such as this is to be recognised—and I do recognise that. On the effectiveness of business, raised by the noble Baroness, Lady Blake, and the need to make sure that people remain in the workforce, having a structure and framework for how neonatal care leave is taken is far more helpful than the current system, which relies, in effect, on the charity of businesses. Many are extremely forward-footed, very generous and very compassionate but, clearly, they do not have a framework in which to operate effectively.
arg2: When discussing these matters, we often reference statistics. In the UK, one in seven babies receive neonatal care before birth, and approximately 50,000 babies stay in neonatal care for over a week after birth. It is important to recognize that each case involves a child and a family, each with unique circumstances. Evidence from families suggests that the current rigidity of parental leave laws exacerbates the challenges they face.

Bill: A Bill to make provision about leave and pay for employees with responsibility for children receiving neonatal care.
arg1: When debating these matters, we get a significant list of statistics. One in seven babies born in the UK receive some level of neonatal care just before birth and an estimated 50,000 babies in the UK spend more than one week in neonatal care after birth. But what we have heard today and need to emphasise is that each one of those cases involves a child and an extended family, and each one of those situations will have very different circumstances. What we know from the feedback from families is that the current inflexibility of the parental leave laws actually contributes to the trauma that they experience and adds to the family’s stress.
arg2: We must open our hearts to the reality that businesses bear a significant cost for providing these crucial social benefits. It is not something we can simply turn a blind eye to. As a compassionate society, we unite to determine our collective path, and we should acknowledge the way businesses strive to meet our needs, particularly on critical issues like this one. I deeply appreciate their efforts. As mentioned by the noble Baroness, Lady Blake, it is vital to ensure that people can remain part of the workforce. Establishing a structured and empathetic framework for taking neonatal care leave is far more supportive than the current system, which depends heavily on the goodwill of businesses. While many are admirably proactive, generous, and compassionate, they lack a structured framework to operate within effectively.

arg1: Let me introduce the House to Sam Bagnall, who I call “our little Sam”, and his doting parents, Zalena and Martin Bagnall, who are watching the debate on this stage of the Bill. Sam decided to come into their lives at a very early stage of her pregnancy: 24 weeks plus two weeks’ gestation. Mum had been on bed rest for a week, praying that she could get to the 24-week stage of viability. And he did, but that was where their lives—three lives—were placed on a hugely emotional journey of many tests, operations and making life decisions, with Sam’s tiny body fighting to survive. Can you imagine being constantly told, “We will do all our best, but you may have to say goodbye to Sam”?
arg2: The Bill goes to the heart of what is hugely important to these families, too many of whom are asked to choose between their livelihoods, work and obligations, and their time with their child. This debate reminds me of the debates we had on what is now the Parental Bereavement (Leave and Pay) Act 2018, which those who were Members of the House back in 2017 and 2018 will remember. In those debates, we talked about the fact that many businesses do the right thing and make support available, even though they are not compelled by statute to go as far as we will hopefully move towards today, but some do not, which is why it is right that we legislate through this Bill to put that right and fill the gap.

Bill: A Bill to make provision about leave and pay for employees with responsibility for children receiving neonatal care.
arg1: The Bill's provisions are a lifeline for parents facing the harrowing experience of having a baby in neonatal care. Imagine the overwhelming relief it brings to fathers and those on paternity leave, allowing them to stay by their newborn's side during such a fragile time. This emotional support is invaluable, as it means fathers can share the burden of anxiety and fear with their partners, who are often left to navigate these turbulent waters alone. It allows them to hold their partner's hand through the heart-wrenching moments of receiving difficult news and making pivotal decisions about their child's future. The ability for both parents to be present is not just a logistical benefit; it is a profound emotional comfort that strengthens the family bond and fosters a nurturing environment crucial for the baby's recovery. This Bill doesn't just change policies; it transforms lives, offering hope and connection to those who need it most in their darkest hours.
arg2: I have talked about the scale of the problem, but I also want to talk about the intensity of the problem. These are some of the most traumatic moments that any parent will go through. My hon. Friend the Member for Thornbury and Yate talked very powerfully about the mental health issues that parents may suffer. I was also quite surprised to read that 66% of fathers end up having to go back to work while their child is in neonatal care. Bill: A Bill to prohibit the import and export of shark fins and to make provision relating to the removal of fins from sharks.
arg1: Leaving the European Union has given us the freedom to protect our oceans and the majestic creatures within them. With this newfound independence, we can take a bold stand against the cruel and inhumane practice of shark finning by banning the import and export of detached shark fins in the UK. Imagine the relief and safety this brings to the vulnerable shark populations, who are often left to suffer and die for the sake of a tasteless delicacy. By implementing this Bill, we are not only preserving the beauty and balance of marine ecosystems but also taking a moral stand against a practice that has long been a blight on our conscience. The only time we will allow these fins to cross our borders is when it contributes to the noble cause of shark conservation, such as through educational programs or specialized training. We have put in place rigorous checks to ensure that any exception is truly in the spirit of protecting these magnificent creatures, reinforcing our commitment to a future where sharks can thrive without the threat of finning.
arg2: Shark finning is a uniquely cruel practice, whereby a shark’s fin is sliced off while the shark is still alive—the rest of the body is discarded. The UK does not support this cruel trade, and it is rightly banned in our waters. By supporting this Bill, the Government will send out a clear message to those countries that do support it, and again I thank the hon. Member for Neath for pointing out that our European neighbour, Spain, is one of the main perpetrators of this practice. We have a proud record on animal welfare and environmental sustainability, often well in advance of EU regulations, and this Bill will strengthen that record further. I share her hope that, where we lead, Europe follows.

Bill: A Bill to prohibit the import and export of shark fins and to make provision relating to the removal of fins from sharks.
arg1: Imagine a world where the silent giants of the ocean, the majestic sharks, glide through the waters with grace, only to be ruthlessly hunted for their fins. These magnificent creatures, having roamed the Earth for over 400 million years, deserve our admiration and protection, not exploitation. Picture the gentle basking shark, the largest fish in UK waters, as it peacefully swims, its size comparable to a double-decker bus. The thought of such a noble creature suffering for mere human vanity is heart-wrenching. By banning the import and export of detached shark fins, we can ensure that these awe-inspiring beings continue to play their crucial role in marine ecosystems, keeping the ocean's delicate balance intact for generations to come. Let us act with compassion and responsibility to safeguard the future of our planet's ancient guardians.
arg2: I am also grateful to the noble Baroness, Lady Parminter, who again reminded us of the international opportunities that we have to press the case and to ensure that we play a leading part internationally in delivering not only these sorts of measures but a wide range of other marine conservation measures. She made the point, as other noble Lords did, about the cruelty that underlines it. It is purely a cruel thing to do. Even if people feel that the cruelty itself is not sufficient, it is also such a waste that you then throw the remaining carcass back into the sea and that it is not used in any useful way, so there are so many strong arguments for this.

Bill: A Bill to prohibit the import and export of shark fins and to make provision relating to the removal of fins from sharks.

arg2: I acknowledge the noble Baroness, Lady Parminter, for highlighting the international opportunities available to advocate for these measures and to ensure a leading role in implementing various marine conservation strategies. Beyond its inefficiency, the disposal of the remaining carcass into the sea results in resource wastage, supporting the case for these measures.
